frameDefinitions: An Agent causes Air to move in a direction, usually specifying either in or out of the body.
These words refer to separating a Whole into Parts, or separating one part from another.
In this frame an Ingestor takes a Substance into his or her body.
A physical Exerter, Action, or Force exerts energy at a level specified by the target.
A physical entity, construed as a point-Sound_source, emits a Sound.
In this frame a Speaker ceases speaking, sometimes about a particular Topic.
frameExamples: I <t>divided</t> the class into groups in alphabetical order .
You should refrain from <t>taking</t> vodka up the nose.
Although an <t>energetic</t> and able warrior, Charlemagne tended to direct battles rather than fight in person.
Finally, Jan <t>shut</t> <t>up</t> about his car accident.
listRoleDefinitions: The <fen>Agent</fen>'s breathing causes the motion of the <fen>Air</fen>.  <fen>Agent</fen> is generally the External Argument.
<fen>Air</fen> is the substance that the <fen>Agent</fen> causes to move.
The time at which breathing occurs.
This role identifies the <fen>Place</fen> where the breathing occurs.
The <fen>Whole</fen> is a single entity or an aggregate of entities which is separated into <fen>Parts</fen>.  It is usually the NP Object of a target verb.
This refers collectively to the Parts resulting from separation of a Whole:
Part-1 is the first of two Parts mentioned. This is most often the Object of a verb.
<fen>Part_2</fen> is the second of two <fen>Parts</fen> mentioned. This is usually a PP Complement. First,
With causative uses of these verbs, an Agent separates or divides something.  The Agent is usually expressed as the External Argument:
The <fen>Cause</fen> is the non-agent that brings about the separation.
This role identifies the <fen>Time</fen> when the separation occurs.
Where the separation occurs.
The <fen>Delivery_device</fen> is the means by which the <fen>Substance</fen> is ingested.
The <fen>Ingestor</fen> ingests the <fen>Substance</fen>.
The <fen>Substance</fen> is the drug or other substance that is ingested by the <fen>Ingestor</fen>.
The <fen>Time</fen> at which the <fen>Ingestor</fen> ingests the <fen>Substance</fen>.
The <fen>Place</fen> where the <fen>Ingestor</fen> ingests the <fen>Substance</fen>.
The <fen>Action</fen> that exerts an energy of the level specified by the target.
The <fen>Exerter</fen> which exerts an energy of the level specified by the target.
The <fen>Force</fen> that exerts an energy of the level specified by the target.
The <fen>Time</fen> during which the <fen>Exerter</fen>, <fen>Action</fen>, or <fen>Force</fen> exerts an energy.
The location where the <fen>Exerter</fen>, <fen>Action</fen>, or <fen>Force</fen> exerts its energy.

The frame element <fen>Sound_source</fen> is assigned to a constituent referring to a physical entity which emits a sound. Such an entity must have an appropriately complex internal structure such that it can create a sound. For example, a machine or some other thing with moving parts can create sound by itself.

The frame element <fen>Sound</fen> is incorporated in the meaning of the verbs of this frame. Otherwise, this role is assigned to NPs which actually refer to a sound in the presence of the target. This typically occurs when the target is a verb used as a modifier in its <ment>-ing</ment> form, e.g.:
An event in which one or more <fen>Sound_source</fen>s participate and which is accompanied by <fen>Sound</fen>.
The time when the <fen>Noisy_event</fen> occurs.

The location of the <fen>Sound_source</fen>. This role differs from <fen>Location_of_source</fen> only in terms of point of view; the latter role implies a point of view that is not on the <fen>Sound_source</fen>.
The <fen>Speaker</fen> has previously been speaking but has now stopped.
The <fen>Expressor</fen> is the <fen>Speaker</fen>'s voice or other communicative noise emitted by the <fen>Speaker</fen>.
The <fen>Time</fen> is when the becoming silent occurs.
The <fen>Place</fen> is the location where the becoming silent occurs.
listRoleExamples: <fex>Lee</fex> breathed the hot desert air.
Lee breathed <fex>the hot desert air</fex>.
All I know is that he was still breathing <fex>at 2AM</fex>.
Lee breathed with difficulty <fex>on the track</fex>.
The directors split <fex>the company</fex> in two.
The directors split the company <fex>in two</fex>.
First, separate <fex>the yolks</fex> from the whites.
separate the yolks <fex>from the whites</fex>.
<fex>The researcher</fex> divided subjects into groups.
I divided the prize money among the winners <fex>that night</fex>.
You should separate the yolks from the whites <fex>over the sink</fex>.
Tabitha smoked <fex>a pipe</fex>.
He was given a vigorous <fex>slap</fex> on the ear for his behavior.
More deadly and painful is the chemical weaponry of the camouflaged but lethargic <fex>stonefish</fex>.
They were trying to harness some of the lightening's intense <fex>power</fex>.
Charlie's workout was intense even <fex>first thing in the morning</fex>.
Because of the added space, our ultimate frisbee game was more vigorous <fex>in Golden Gate Park</fex>.
<fex>The wind</fex> howled.
The branches made a rattling <fex>sound</fex>.
<fex>The conversations</fex> droned on
It's going to beep again <fex>in two minutes</fex>.
A bat squeaked <fex>over our heads</fex>.
<fex>The children</fex> finally quieted down.
<fex>The excited chatter</fex> hushed.
